current-chamber.#text: IN THE SENATE OF THE UNITED STATES

quote.#tail:
, for outstanding heroism,
		  valor, skill, and service to the United States in conducting the bombings of
		  Tokyo.

official-title.#text:
To award a Congressional Gold Medal to the World War II
		  members of the

quote.#tail:
for outstanding heroism, valor, skill,
			 and service to the United States in conducting the bombings of Tokyo;

text.#text:
on April 18,
			 1942, the brave men of the 17th Bombardment Group (Medium) became known as the

80 brave American
			 aircraft crewmen, led by Lieutenant Colonel James Doolittle, volunteered for an

after the
			 discovery of the USS Hornet by Japanese picket ships 170 miles further away
			 from the prearranged launch point, the Doolittle Tokyo Raiders proceeded to
			 take off 670 miles from the coast of Japan;

by launching more
			 than 100 miles beyond the distance considered to be minimally safe for the
			 mission, the Doolittle Tokyo Raiders deliberately accepted the risk that the
			 B–25s might not have enough fuel to reach the designated air-fields in China on
			 return;

the additional
			 launch distance greatly increased the risk of crash landing in Japanese
			 occupied China, exposing the crews to higher probability of death, injury, or
			 capture;

because of that
			 deliberate choice, after bombing their targets in Japan, low on fuel and in
			 setting night and deteriorating weather, none of the 16 airplanes reached the
			 prearranged Chinese airfields;

of the 8 captured
			 Doolittle Tokyo Raiders, 3 were executed and 1 died of disease; and

there were only
			 5 surviving members of the Doolittle Tokyo Raiders as of February 2013.

shall make appropriate arrangements for the award, on behalf of
			 Congress, of 6 gold medals of appropriate design in honor of the World War II
			 members of the 17th Bombardment Group (Medium) who became known as the
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text:
Speaker of the House of
			 Representatives
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Speaker of the House of Representatives

quote.#tail:
, in recognition of their military
			 service during World War II.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
shall strike the gold medals with suitable
			 emblems, devices, and inscriptions, to be determined by the

text.#text: For the purposes of the award referred to in

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
, 5 of the gold medals shall be given to the 5 surviving members of the mission as of February 2013  or their next of kin, with a sixth medal to be given to the National Museum of the United States Air
			 Force, where it shall be displayed with the Doolittle Tokyo Raiders Goblets, as
			 appropriate, and made available for research.

text.#text: Following the award of the gold medals referred to in

that the National Museum of
			 the United States Air Force should make the gold medal received under

available for display elsewhere, particularly at other locations and
			 events associated with the Doolittle Tokyo Raiders.

may strike and sell duplicates in bronze of the gold medal struck
			 under this Act, at a price sufficient to cover the costs of the medals,
			 including labor, materials, dyes, use of machinery, and overhead
			 expenses.

text.#text:
Medals struck pursuant to this Act are national medals for

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: , all medals struck under this Act are numismatic items.

{http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/}title.#text: 113 S381 ES: To award a Congressional Gold Medal to the World War II members of the “Doolittle Tokyo Raiders”, for outstanding heroism, valor, skill, and service to the United States in conducting the bombings of Tokyo.
